body.p: While we will be emphasizing the use of statistical software in obtaining the exact p-value. The critical value method provides the ability to get an understanding of whether or not a null hypothesis will be rejected at a given probability level (ex. .05 or .01). In addition, for the z test, the Normal Table can be used to determine the exact probability level, without the use of statistical software.

section.title: Concepts of the Critical Value Method

body.p: There are several concepts that are important to understand in the critical value method. They are the: 1) critical value and 2) the critical region. As shown in the graph below, the critical value is the value, which cuts off an area referred to as the critical region (or area of rejection), as applied to the z test.

image.alt: A N(0,1) curve with critical values -|z| and |z| marked on the horizontal axis. The area to the left of -|z| is a critical region, and the area to the right of |z| is also a critical region.

body.p: When z test statistics fall in the critical region (the blue shaded areas in the above graph), they are far enough from the mean that they are significantly different from the mean; therefore, in these instances, the null hypothesis would be rejected. The critical region is determined by a critical value that is based on two things: 1) the significance level of the test (either .05 or .01) AND the direction of the test (ex. left-tailed, right-tailed, or two-tailed).

For a two-tailed z test, there will be critical regions on both sides of the distribution. For a two-tailed test using a .05 level of significance, we need to determine a value that would put .025 or 2.5%, in each tail. We can determine this value by using the Normal Table.

First, we need to look in the body of the normal table (click here), where we will see that the exact value .0250 is associated with the z score of -1.96; thus, -1.96 is the critical value that puts .025 (or 2.5%) in the left tail of the distribution. Since the standard normal distribution is symmetrical, +1.96 is the critical value that puts .025 (or 2.5%) in the right tail. Thus, the critical values of -1.96 and +1.96 would define the critical regions for a two-tailed z-test using a .05 significance level.

image.alt: A N(0,1) curve titled "Critical Regions for a Two-Tailed z Test." The curve's horizontal axis has been marked with critical values z = -1.96 and z = 1.96. The area to the left of -1.96 is a critical region, and the area to the right of 1.96 is also a critical region.

body.p: In order to test the null hypothesis, we need to look at where the z-test statistic falls in relation to the critical regions formed by the critical values. In a two-tailed z-test, a z-test statistic of -1.5 would not fall in a critical region Therefore, we know that the p-value would be more than .05. Thus, we would not reject the null hypothesis, since the p-value is greater than .05 (or, stated another way, p-value > .05).

On the other hand, a z-test statistic of -2.5 would fall within the critical region on the left hand side of the distribution; t herefore, we know that the p-value would be less than .05. In this instance, we would reject the null hypothesis at a less than .05 level (or p-value < .05). Furthermore, it is possible to figure out the exact p-value for the z-test statistic of -2.5, by using the Normal Table, which is .0062.

image.alt: The N(0,1) curve on which the critical value has been marked at -1.96 on the horizontal axis. In addition, the observed test statistics -2.5 and -1.5 have been marked. -1.5 is to the right of -1.96 so it is not part of the critical region, but -2.5 is to the left of -1.96, so it is part of the critical region.

body.p: The same logic applies to one-tailed z-tests. For the one-tailed “less than” z-test, the critical value for a .05 significance level is -1.645 (note: since the p-value for -1.64 is .0505 and the p-value for -1.65 is .0495, the critical value for .0500 would be between the two z scores or -1.645).

image.alt: A N(0,1) curve labeled "Critical Region for a 'Less Than' One-Tailed Test." The critical value for .05, -1.645, has been marked on the horizontal axis. The area to the left of this critical value under the curve is the critical region.

body.p: With a “less than” one-tailed z test, any z-test statistic that is less than -1.645, would fall in the critical region and therefore, would have a p-value less than .05. For instance, -2.5 would be less than -1.645 and would fall in the critical region. Thus, it would have a p-value less than .05 and the null hypothesis would be rejected.

Any z-test statistic that is larger than -1.645 would have a probability level of greater than .05 (or p-value > .05). For instance, -1.5 would be greater than -1.645 and, therefore, would not fall in the critical region. Thus, it would have a p-value greater than .05 and the null hypothesis would not be rejected.
For the one-tailed “greater than” z-test, the critical value for a .05 significance level is 1.645.

image.alt: A N(0,1) curve labeled "Critical Region for a 'Greater Than' One-Tailed Test." The critical value 1.645 has been marked on the horizontal axis. The area to the right of this critical value under the curve is the critical region.

body.p: Thus, with a “greater than” one-tailed z test, any z-test statistic larger than 1.645, would fall in the critical region and therefore, would have a p-value less than .05. For instance, 2.5 would be greater than 1.645 and would fall in the critical region. Thus, it would have a p-value less than .05 (or p-value < .05) and the null hypothesis would be rejected .

Any z-test statistic that less than 1.645 would have a probability level of greater than .05 (or p-value>.05). For instance, 1.5 would be less than 1.645 and, therefore, would not fall in the critical region. Thus, it would have a p-value greater than .05 and the null hypothesis would not be rejected.

The critical value method uses two concepts: 1) the critical value and 2) the critical region. The critical value is used to determine the critical region and is based on two things: 1) the significance level of the test (either .05 or .01) AND the direction of the test (ex, left-tailed, right-tailed, or two-tailed).

When z-test statistic falls in the critical region, it is far enough from the mean that it is significantly different from the mean. Therefore, in this instance, the null hypothesis would be rejected at the significance level used to determine the critical region (either .05 or .01). Furthermore, the actual p-value can be determined by using the Normal Table.

When the z-test statistic does not fall in the critical region, it indicates that it is not far enough from the mean to be significantly different from the mean. In this instance, the null hypothesis would not be rejected.

The critical value method has been traditionally used for hypothesis testing (note: there are different critical values and tables for t-tests, ANOVAs, and Chi Square tests). The emphasis now, however, is on the use of exact p-values, which are obtained through the use of statistical software packages.
